problem: A spinless particle (mass \(m\), charge \(q\)) is constrained to move on the perimeter of a circle with a unit circumference. Assume the circle represents half the area of an ellipse's circumference. Determine its allowed energy levels. Without an electric field \(F\) or magnetic field \(B\), the particle's motion is extremely relativistic.
solution:
We use the quantization condition

\[
p \cdot 2 \pi R = n \hbar, \quad p = \frac{n \hbar}{R}
\]

Thus, \(E = p c = \frac{n \hbar}{R} \cdot c\), same as in equation (5).

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
Electrostatic potential near a \({ }^{2} p_{3 / 2}\) ion on an orthogonal lattice

\[
V(r)=A x^{2}+B y^{2}-(A+B) z^{2}
\]

where \(A, B\) are constants. Assume the set of wave functions for the free ion is

\[
\psi_{1}=R(r) Y_{11}, \quad \psi_{0}=R(r) Y_{10}, \quad \psi_{-1}=R(r) Y_{1-1}
\]

Assuming \(V(r)\) is very small, the first-order energy correction of the ground state is \(\pm \sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}\), and each value is two-fold degenerate. If one of the eigenstates corresponding to the positive energy correction value is \(\cos \theta\left|3 / 2\right\rangle+\sin (\theta / 2)\left|-1 / 2\right\rangle\), where \(\theta=\arctan (b / a)\), find the other eigenstate.
solution:
In the case of a free ion, the 4 \(M_{J}\) states are degenerate, so the first-order energy correction of the ground state is given by the eigenvalues of a matrix, and the corresponding eigenfunctions are the eigenvectors of the matrix. If the order of the basis vectors of the matrix is changed from \(M_{J}=3 / 2,1 / 2,-1 / 2,-3 / 2\) to \(M_{J}=3 / 2,-1 / 2,-3 / 2,1 / 2\), the resulting matrix becomes easier to solve. The matrix becomes

\[
\left(\begin{array}{llll}
a & b & 0 & 0 \\
b & -a & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & a & b \\
0 & 0 & b & -a
\end{array}\right)
\]

This decomposes into the direct sum of two \(2 \times 2\) matrices. Since the two \(2 \times 2\) matrices are identical, their eigenvalues and eigenvectors are the same, hence there is still a two-fold degeneracy. From the first \(2 \times 2\) matrix, we get the equation

\[
\left(\begin{array}{cc}
a & b \\
b & -a
\end{array}\right)\binom{p}{q}=\lambda\binom{p}{q}
\]

Solving this gives

\[
\lambda= \pm \sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}, \quad \frac{p}{q}=\frac{\lambda+a}{b}
\]

Let \(\tan \theta=b / a\). When \(\lambda=\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}\), we have

\[
\frac{p}{q}=\frac{\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}+a}{b}=\frac{1+\cos \theta}{\sin \theta}=\frac{\cos (\theta / 2)}{\sin (\theta / 2)}
\]

Using the normalization condition \(p^{2}+q^{2}=1\), we find \(p=\cos (\theta / 2), q=\sin (\theta / 2)\). Similarly, for \(\lambda=-\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}\), we have 

\[
p=\sin (\theta / 2), \quad q=-\cos (\theta / 2)
\]

Thus, the eigenstates corresponding to the eigenvalues \(\lambda= \pm \sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}\) are

\[
\begin{cases}
\cos \frac{\theta}{2}\left|\frac{3}{2}\right\rangle+\sin \frac{\theta}{2}\left|-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle=|1\rangle \\
\sin \frac{\theta}{2}\left|\frac{3}{2}\right\rangle-\cos \frac{\theta}{2}\left|-\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle=|2\rangle
\end{cases}
\]

Similarly, solving the eigenvalue equation for the second \(2 \times 2\) matrix, one can obtain the eigenvalues \(\lambda^{\prime}= \pm \sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}}\), with the corresponding eigenvectors

\[
\begin{cases}
\cos \frac{\theta}{2}\left|-\frac{3}{2}\right\rangle+\sin \frac{\theta}{2}\left|\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle=|3\rangle \\
\sin \frac{\theta}{2}\left|-\frac{3}{2}\right\rangle-\cos \frac{\theta}{2}\left|\frac{1}{2}\right\rangle=|4\rangle
\end{cases}
\]

subject: Quantum Mechanics
Quantum Mechanics
Quantum Mechanics
problem:
In a one-dimensional harmonic oscillator potential, there are $N$ (where $N$ is a large number) spinless fermions interacting pairwise through a repulsive $\delta$ function potential

$$
V=\frac{k}{2} \sum_{i=1}^{N} x_{i}^{2}+\frac{\lambda}{2} \sum_{i \neq j} \delta\left(x_{i}-x_{j}\right), \quad k, \lambda>0
$$

Express the three lowest energy normalized wave functions and energies using the normalized harmonic oscillator single-particle wave functions $\psi_{n}(x)$. What is the degeneracy of these energy levels?
solution:
Treat the $\delta$ function potential as a perturbation. The zeroth-order wave function of the system can be written using the Slater determinant

$$
\psi_{n_1\cdots n_N}\left(x_{1}, \cdots, x_{N}\right) =\frac{1}{\sqrt{N!}} \left\lvert\, \begin{array}{cccc}
\psi_{n_1}\left(x_{1}\right) & \psi_{n_1}\left(x_{2}\right) & \cdots & \psi_{n_1}\left(x_{N}\right) \\
\psi_{n_2}\left(x_{1}\right) & \psi_{n_2}\left(x_{2}\right) & \cdots & \psi_{n_2}\left(x_{N}\right) \\
\vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\
\psi_{n_N}\left(x_{1}\right) & \psi_{n_N}\left(x_{2}\right) & \cdots & \psi_{n_N}\left(x_{N}\right)
\end{array} \right\rvert
$$

Due to the antisymmetry of the wave function with respect to $x_{i}, x_{j}(i \neq j)$, the matrix elements of the $\delta$ potential are all zero, having no impact on the zeroth-order system. The energy levels are

$$
E_{(n_1\cdots n_N)}=\left\langle n_{1} \cdots n_{N}\right| H\left|n_{1} \cdots n_{N}\right\rangle=\hbar \omega\left(\frac{N}{2}+\sum_{i=1}^{N} n_{i}\right)
$$

where $\omega=\sqrt{k / m}, n_{1} \cdots n_{N}$ are pairwise distinct.

(i) Ground State:
$n_{1}, \cdots, n_{N}$ are arranged in the order $0,1, \cdots, N-1$

$$
E_{0,1, \cdots, N-1}=\hbar \omega\left[\frac{N}{2}+\frac{N(N-1)}{2}\right]=\frac{\hbar \omega}{2} N^{2}
$$

The wave function is

$$
\psi_{0,1, \cdots, N-1}\left(x_{1}, \cdots, x_{N}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N!}} \sum_{P} \delta_{P} P\left[\psi_{0}\left(x_{1}\right) \cdots \psi_{N-1}\left(x_{N}\right)\right]
$$

(ii) First Excited State:
$n_{1}, \cdots, n_{N}$ are arranged in the order $0,1, \cdots, N-2, N$

$$
E_{0,1, \cdots, N-2, N}=\frac{1}{2} \hbar \omega\left(N^{2}+2\right)
$$

The wave function is

$$
\psi_{0,1, \cdots, N-2, N}\left(x_{1}, \cdots, x_{N}\right)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N!}} \sum_{P} \delta_{P} P\left[\psi_{0}\left(x_{1}\right) \cdots \psi_{N-2}\left(x_{N-1}\right) \psi_{N}\left(x_{N}\right)\right]
$$

(iii) Second Excited State:
There are two arrangements for $n_{1}, \cdots, n_{N}$

$$
\{0,1, \cdots, N-2, N+1 \} \quad \text{and} \quad \{0,1, \cdots, N-3, N-1, N \}
$$

The energy is

$$
E_{0,1, \cdots, N-2, N+1}=E_{0,1, \cdots, N-3, N-1, N}=\frac{\hbar \omega}{2}\left(N^{2}+4\right)
$$

There are two wave functions

$$
\begin{align*}
\psi_{0,1, \cdots, N-2, N+1}\left(x_{1}, \cdots, x_{N}\right) &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N!}} \sum_{P} \delta_{P} P\left[\psi_{0}\left(x_{1}\right) \cdots \psi_{N-2}\left(x_{N-1}\right) \psi_{N+1}\left(x_{N}\right)\right], \\
\psi_{0,1, \cdots, N-3, N-1, N}\left(x_{1}, \cdots, x_{N}\right) &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{N!}} \sum_{P} \delta_{P} P\left[\psi_{0}\left(x_{1}\right) \cdots \psi_{N-3}\left(x_{N-2}\right) \psi_{N-1}\left(x_{N-1}\right) \psi_{N}\left(x_{N}\right)\right]
\end{align*}
$$

From this, we can immediately see that the ground state and first excited state are non-degenerate, while the second excited state is doubly degenerate.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
The study of high-energy electron scattering by nuclei provides very useful information about the charge distribution within nuclei and nucleons. Here we consider a simple modification of this theory, assuming electrons have zero spin, and we also assume a nucleus with charge \(Z\) is fixed in space (i.e., possessing infinite mass). The nuclear charge distribution is assumed to be spherically symmetric, with no further restrictions. Let \(\rho(x)\) denote the nuclear charge density.

Let \(\boldsymbol{p}_{i}, \boldsymbol{p}_{f}\) represent the initial and final momentum of the electrons, respectively. The scattering amplitude for an electron being scattered by a point nucleus (charge \(Z\)) in the first Born approximation is denoted by \(f_{\mathrm{e}}\left(\boldsymbol{p}_{i}, \boldsymbol{p}_{f}\right)\). Meanwhile, \(f\left(\boldsymbol{p}_{i}, \boldsymbol{p}_{f}\right)\) denotes the scattering amplitude for an electron being scattered by an actual nucleus with the same charge in the first Born approximation. Let \(q = p_{i} - p_{f}\) represent the momentum transfer. The quantity \(F\) is defined as

\[
f\left(\boldsymbol{p}_{i}, \boldsymbol{p}_{f}\right) = F\left(q^{2}\right) f_{\mathrm{e}}\left(\boldsymbol{p}_{i}, \boldsymbol{p}_{f}\right)
\]

and it is called the form factor. It is easy to see that \(F\) only depends on \(q^{2}\) with regard to \(\left(\boldsymbol{p}_{i}, \boldsymbol{p}_{f}\right)\). (1) There is a simple relationship between the form factor \(F\left(q^{2}\right)\) and the Fourier transform of the charge density \(\rho(x)\). In the framework of non-relativistic Schrdinger theory, describe and derive this relationship. The assumption of non-relativistic motion for the electrons is merely to simplify the problem as much as possible, and upon careful consideration, it can be seen that this assumption is irrelevant, meaning the relativistic case applicable to experiments shares the same conclusion. Similarly, ignoring electron spin does not affect the essence of the problem at hand.
answers: \boxed{F\left(q^{2}\right)=\frac{4 \pi}{Z e} \int_{0}^{\infty} \mathrm{d} r r^{2} \rho(r) \frac{\sin q r}{q r}}

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A spin-less particle (with mass \(m\) and charge \(q\)) is constrained to move on a circle with radius \(R\). In the absence of an electric field \(F\) and a magnetic field \(B\), the particle's motion is extremely relativistic. Determine the allowed energy levels.
solution:
Due to the large momentum, the W.K.B. approximation can be used, or from the quantization condition

\[
p \cdot 2 \pi R = n \hbar, \quad p = n \hbar / R
\]

then in the extreme relativistic case

\[
E = pc = n \hbar / R \cdot c, \quad n=0,1,2, \cdots
\]

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A beam of spin-$1/2$ particles passes through a Stern-Gerlach apparatus, and based on the particles quantum number $m_{s}$, the incident particle beam splits into two beams. One of the beams is removed, and the other passes through a similar apparatus, where the magnetic field is inclined at an angle $\alpha$ relative to the first apparatus. If the particles remaining after leaving the first Stern-Gerlach apparatus are spin-up, what is the relative number of particles in the two beams after leaving the second apparatus? Apply the Pauli spin matrices to derive the result.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: In a rigid rotor model with a moment of inertia $I$ and an electric dipole moment $d$, a diatomic molecule is placed in a weak electric field $E$, neglecting the motion of the center of mass. Express the rotor's Hamiltonian in the form of $H_{0}+H^{\prime}$.
solution:
The Hamiltonian can be expressed as:
$$
H = \frac{1}{2 I} J^{2} - \boldsymbol{d} \cdot \boldsymbol{E} = \frac{1}{2 I} J^{2} - d E \cos \theta
$$
where $H_{0} = \frac{1}{2 I} J^{2}$, and $H^{\prime} = -d E \cos \theta$.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: During the heating process of a blackbody, it is measured that its maximum monochromatic radiance changes from $0.69 \, \mu \mathrm{m}$ to $0.50 \, \mu \mathrm{m}$. Find the factor by which the temperature changes, i.e., $T_{2}/T_{1}$.
solution:
According to Wien's displacement law

$$
\lambda_{m} T = b
$$

where $b$ is a constant. Thus, we have

$$
\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}} = \frac{\lambda_{1}}{\lambda_{2}}
$$

Substituting $\lambda_{1} = 0.69 \, \mu \mathrm{m}, \lambda_{2} = 0.50 \, \mu \mathrm{m}$, we get

$$
\frac{T_{2}}{T_{1}} = \frac{0.69}{0.50} = 1.38
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A polar explorer uses a lens made of ice to converge sunlight and ignite kindling. Given that the lens diameter is $d=0.20 \, \mathrm{m}$, the diameter of the sun is $D=1.4 \times 10^{6} \, \mathrm{km}$, the distance from the Earth to the sun is $z=1.5 \times 10^{8} \, \mathrm{km}$, and the sun's radiance is $B=2.0 \times 10^{7} \, \mathrm{W} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{-2} \cdot \mathrm{sr}^{-1}$. Please calculate the light power that the lens can collect when facing the sun directly.
solution:
The light power collected by the lens when facing the sun is

$$
E = B \cdot \left(\frac{\pi}{4} D^{2}\right) \cdot \frac{\frac{\pi}{4} d^{2}}{z^{2}} = 44 \, \mathrm{W}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: In a nuclear explosion, the instantaneous temperature of the fireball can reach $10^{7} \mathrm{~K}$. Estimate the wavelength of the most intense radiation.
solution:
Approximating as a black body, according to Wien's law, we have

$$
\lambda = \frac{b}{T} = \frac{0.288 \text{ cm K}}{10^{7} \mathrm{~K}} \approx 0.3 \mathrm{~nm}
$$

This falls within the X-ray wavelength range.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: As shown in the figure, two mutually perpendicular reflective planes are placed in a parallel beam of light, with reflective coefficients of $k_{2}$ and $k_{1}$ respectively. If the brightness of one reflective plane is to be equal to that of the other, find the angle $\alpha_{2}$ between this plane and the parallel beam, assuming the reflective planes obey Lambert's Law.
solution:
$$
\alpha_{2} = \tan^{-1} \left(\frac{k_{1}}{k_{2}}\right)
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
The total radiation power of the Sun is $38.17 \times 10^{22} \, \mathrm{kW}$. Find:

(2) The Sun's mass loss rate.
solution:
(2) According to the mass-energy equivalence $E=mc^{2}$:

$$
\Delta m=\frac{\Delta E}{c^{2}}=\frac{38.17 \times 10^{22} \, \mathrm{kW}}{\left(3 \times 10^{8} \, \mathrm{m/s}\right)^{2}}=4.24 \times 10^{9} \, \mathrm{kg/s}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: The solar constant is $S = 1.35 \, \mathrm{kW/m^2}$. If the sun decreases in mass at this constant rate, how much mass does the sun lose each year? The distance from the Earth to the sun is $1.5 \times 10^{11} \, \mathrm{m}$.
solution:
The total radiation power of the sun is given by $4 \pi r^{2} \cdot S$, where $r$ is the Earth-sun distance. According to $E = mc^2$, the mass decreases per second by

$$
m = \frac{4 \pi r^{2} \cdot S}{c^2} = \frac{3.8 \times 10^{26}}{9 \times 10^{16}} = 4.2 \times 10^9 \, \mathrm{kg/s}
$$

Considering that each year has $3.2 \times 10^{7} \, \mathrm{s}$, the sun loses $1.4 \times 10^{17} \, \mathrm{kg}$ per year.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Solar energy is incident on a solar panel heating water at a radiation flux of $800 \mathrm{~W}/\mathrm{m}^2$. Assume the absorption rate of the panel is $0.96$ for all wavelengths, and the other surfaces are completely adiabatic. Calculate the maximum possible temperature of the water.
solution:
According to the Stefan-Boltzmann law

$$
\alpha \phi = \sigma T^{4}, \quad T = \sqrt[4]{\frac{\alpha \phi}{\sigma}}
$$

Substituting

$$
\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \cdot \mathrm{~K}^{4}, \quad \phi = 800 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}, \quad \alpha = 0.96
$$

yields

$$
T_{\max} = 341 \mathrm{~K}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Estimate the efficiency of an incandescent light bulb (the ratio of visible light power to actual power consumption).
solution: The efficiency of an incandescent light bulb is approximately 0.02.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: How many electrons pass through the filament of a light bulb every second? Choose the most appropriate answer from the following options: $10^{10}, 10^{15}, 10^{19}, 10^{25}$. Assume the bulb's power is $P=100 \mathrm{~W}$ and the voltage is $100 \mathrm{~V}$.
solution: The current $I$ can be determined using the formula $P=IV$: $I = \frac{P}{V} = \frac{100 \mathrm{~W}}{100 \mathrm{~V}} = 1 \mathrm{~A}$. The number of electrons passing per second is $n=\frac{I}{e}=\frac{1}{1.6 \times 10^{-19}} \approx 10^{19} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}$. Therefore, the most appropriate answer is $10^{19}$.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: What is the energy flux density of sunlight at Earth's orbital path? Choose the most appropriate answer from the following options: $10^{6}, 10^{2}, 10^{-1}, 10^{-5} \mathrm{~W/cm}^{2}$. Given that the irradiance $I=1.4 \mathrm{~kW/m}^{2}$.
solution: The irradiance $I=1.4 \mathrm{~kW/m}^{2}$ converts to $\mathrm{W/cm}^{2}$ as $0.14 \mathrm{~W/cm}^{2} \approx 0.1 \mathrm{~W/cm}^{2}$. Therefore, the most appropriate answer is $10^{-1} \mathrm{~W/cm}^{2}$.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
When the Earth directly faces the Sun, the solar radiation power received per unit area is $e=1.35 \, \mathrm{kW/m}^2$, which is called the solar constant. The distance from the Earth to the Sun is $r_{1}=1.50 \times 10^{8} \, \mathrm{km}$. Calculate:

(1) The total power of solar radiation.
solution:
(1) Total power of solar radiation
$$
\psi=4 \pi r_{1}^{2} e=38.17 \times 10^{22} \, \mathrm{kW}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Light with a wavelength of 200 nm is incident on an aluminum surface. It is known that the energy required to remove an electron is 4.2 eV. What is the stopping voltage?
solution: The stopping voltage is 2.0 V.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Light with a wavelength of 200 nm is incident on an aluminum surface. Given that the energy required to remove an electron is 4.2 eV, what is the energy of the fastest emitted photoelectron?
solution:
The energy of the photon is calculated as:

$$
E = \frac{h c}{\lambda} = \frac{6.626 \times 10^{-34} \times 3 \times 10^{8}}{200 \times 10^{-9} \times 1.602 \times 10^{-19}} \text{ eV} = 6.2 \text{ eV}
$$

The energy of the fastest emitted photoelectron is:

$$
W = h \nu - A = 6.2 - 4.2 = 2.0 \text{ eV}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Design a solar-powered bathroom to heat 10 tons of water from $14^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $50^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Assume the energy density of the sun near the Earth is $1.4 \, \mathrm{kW/m}^{2}$, and the thermal efficiency of the solar panel is $41.8\%$. Calculate the required area of the solar panel to complete the heating within 1 hour.
solution:
The heat required to heat the water

$$
Q = m c \Delta T = 3.6 \times 10^{8} \, \mathrm{cal} = 3.6 \times 4.18 \times 10^{8} \, \mathrm{J}
$$

Considering the thermal efficiency, the panel actually needs to receive the heat $Q^{\prime} = Q / \eta$

$$
Q^{\prime} = I S t
$$

where $I = 1.4 \, \mathrm{kW/m}^2$, $S$ is the area, $t = 3600 \, \mathrm{s}$,

$$
S = \frac{Q^{\prime}}{I t} = \frac{Q}{I t \eta} = \frac{3.6 \times 10^{8} \times 4.18}{1.4 \times 10^{3} \times 3.6 \times 10^{3} \times 0.418} = 714 \, \mathrm{m}^{2}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Is the "lifetime" of the Sun calculated using this method, which is approximately over ten trillion years, accurate?
solution: The "lifetime" calculated using this method is not accurate. It is necessary to calculate based on the time required for the hydrogen in the Sun to be completely exhausted due to thermonuclear reactions. By that time, even without performing thermonuclear reactions and thus no longer emitting light, a large amount of helium still exists, but the "Sun" is already "dead."

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: The pulse output power of a nitrogen molecular laser is $I=600 \, \mathrm{kW}$, and its beam is focused on a target area of $1 \, \mathrm{mm}^{2}$. Calculate the radiation pressure on the target.
solution:
The relationship between photon energy and momentum is given by $E=p c$, therefore

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d} E}{\mathrm{~d} t}=c \frac{\mathrm{~d} p}{\mathrm{~d} t}
$$

The target completely absorbs the momentum of the light, according to the impulse-momentum theorem, the force exerted is $F$

$$
F=\frac{\mathrm{d} p}{\mathrm{~d} t}=\frac{1}{c} \frac{\mathrm{~d} E}{\mathrm{~d} t}
$$

Pressure

$$
P=\frac{F}{S}=\frac{1}{c S} \frac{\mathrm{~d} E}{\mathrm{~d} t}=\frac{600 \times 10^{3}}{3 \times 10^{8} \times 1 \times 10^{-6}}=2 \times 10^{3} \, \mathrm{Pa}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Assume there is a spherical celestial body in the solar system, located at a distance from the Sun equal to the Earth's distance from the Sun, \( R = 1.5 \times 10^{11} \, \mathrm{m} \). Assume the Sun is equivalent to a black body with a temperature of \( T_c = 6000 \, \mathrm{K} \) and a radius of \( R_c = 7 \times 10^{8} \, \mathrm{m} \). Determine the temperature of the celestial body based on the following assumption: The celestial body has black body characteristics.
solution:
Assume the diameter of the celestial body is \( d \). Since it is a black body, the absorption coefficient is \( \alpha = 1 \). The absorbed power is

$$
P_1 = \alpha \frac{\pi d^2}{4} \cdot \sigma T_c^4 \left(\frac{R_c}{R}\right)^2.
$$

The total power radiated by the celestial body in all directions is

$$
P_2 = \pi d^2 \cdot \sigma T^4.
$$

In equilibrium, \( P_1 = P_2 \), therefore

$$
T = T_c \sqrt{\frac{R_c}{2R}} = 290 \, \mathrm{K}.
$$

This is approximately equal to the average temperature on the Earth's surface. Note: This conclusion is independent of the size of the celestial body.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: In Compton scattering, determine the relationship between the kinetic energy \( K \) of the recoiling electron and the energy \( E \) of the incident photon. Express using the incident wavelength \( \lambda_{0} \) and the scattered wavelength \( \lambda' \). Hint: Consider the energy states of the photon before and after the collision.
solution:
Before and after the collision, the energy of the photon is respectively

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E = h \nu_{0} = \frac{hc}{\lambda_{0}}, \\
& E^{\prime} = h \nu^{\prime} = \frac{hc}{\lambda'}.
\end{aligned}
$$

By energy conservation, the kinetic energy of the recoiling electron is

$$
K = E - E^{\prime}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Assume that an X-ray with a wavelength of \( 0.100 \, \mathrm{nm} \) collides with a free electron and is observed at an angle of \( 90^{\circ} \) to the incident direction. Calculate the proportion of the incident light's energy that is lost after the collision.
solution:
Given the equation
\[
\frac{K}{E} = \frac{2 \lambda_{c} \sin^{2}(\theta / 2)}{\lambda_{0} + 2 \lambda_{c} \sin^{2}(\theta / 2)}
\]
when \( \theta = 90^{\circ} \), it simplifies to
\[
\frac{K}{E} = \frac{\lambda_{c}}{\lambda_{0} + \lambda_{c}}
\]
For \( \lambda_{0} = 0.100 \, \mathrm{nm} \), the result is
\[
\frac{K}{E} = 2.35\%
\]

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Light with a wavelength of 200 nm shines on an aluminum surface. The energy required to remove an electron is known to be 4.2 eV. If the intensity of the incident light is \(2.0 \, \mathrm{W/m^2}\), what is the average number of photons hitting the unit area per unit time?
solution:
The relationship between light intensity and the average photon flux \(N\) is given by:

\[
I = N h \nu
\]

\[
N = \frac{I}{h \nu} = \frac{I \lambda}{h c} = \frac{2.0 \times 10^{-19}}{6.626 \times 10^{-34} \times 3 \times 10^{8}} = 2 \times 10^{8} \, \text{m}^{-2} \cdot \text{s}^{-1}
\]

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
Derive from Planck's formula for blackbody radiation the number of photons emitted per square meter of a blackbody within a unit steradian per micrometer wavelength interval, \( n_{\lambda} \), as

$$
n_{\lambda} = \frac{2c}{\lambda^{4} \left(e^{hc/\lambda kT} - 1\right)}
$$
solution:
The radiated power per square meter, per steradian, in the direction normal to the blackbody within the wavelength range from \(\lambda\) to \(\lambda + \mathrm{d} \lambda\), also known as monochromatic radiance, can be written using Planck's formula as

$$
b_{\lambda, T} = 2hc^{2} \lambda^{-5} \frac{1}{e^{hc/\lambda kT} - 1}
$$

Assuming the energy of each photon is \(\varepsilon = h \frac{c}{\lambda}\), then

$$
b_{\lambda, T} = n_{\lambda, T} \varepsilon
$$

Therefore,

$$
n_{\lambda, T} = \frac{b_{\lambda, T}}{\varepsilon} = \frac{2c}{\lambda^{4}} \frac{1}{e^{hc/\lambda kT} - 1}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Assume the Sun becomes a black hole. Calculate its gravitational radius. Understand that if the Sun's mass $M$ becomes a black hole, photons cannot escape from the radius of this celestial body.
solution:
The approximation in the above formula is due to the simple calculation showing that if the Sun becomes a black hole, its diameter needs to be compressed to 3 km. Therefore, for a celestial body of mass $M$ to become a black hole, its gravitational radius is

$$
3 \frac{M}{M_{c}} \mathrm{~km}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
Gravitational redshift of a photon. A photon with energy $h 
u$ is emitted from the Earth's surface towards infinity. Find the frequency $
u^{\prime}$ observed at infinity, assuming $
u^{\prime} \approx 
u$.
solution:
According to

$$
E = h \nu, \quad E = m c^{2}
$$

the gravitational mass of the photon $m = \frac{h \nu}{c^{2}}$. Since $\nu^{\prime} \approx \nu$, we can assume the gravitational mass of this photon remains unchanged. The work done in overcoming gravity when traveling towards infinity is

$$
\int_{R}^{\infty} \frac{h \nu}{c^{2}} \frac{G M}{r^{2}} \mathrm{d}r = \frac{h \nu}{c^{2}} \frac{G M}{R}
$$

In the formula, $G$ is the gravitational constant, and $M$ and $R$ are the mass and radius of the Earth, respectively. Hence, the frequency $\nu^{\prime}$ observed at infinity is

$$
\nu^{\prime} = \nu \left(1 - \frac{G M}{R c^{2}}\right)
$$

or

$$
\frac{\Delta \nu}{\nu} = -\frac{G M}{R c^{2}}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Assume that the \( \gamma \)-ray with a wavelength of \( 0.188 \times 10^{-2} \, \mathrm{nm} \) from a cesium \( \mathrm{Cs}^{137} \) sample collides with a free electron. Observing from an angle of \( 90^{\circ} \) relative to the incident direction, find the proportion of the incident energy lost after the collision relative to the total energy.
solution:
Since
\[
\frac{K}{E} = \frac{2 \lambda_{c} \sin^{2}(\theta / 2)}{\lambda_{0} + 2 \lambda_{c} \sin^{2}(\theta / 2)}
\]
When \( \theta = 90^{\circ} \)
\[
\frac{K}{E} = \frac{\lambda_{c}}{\lambda_{0} + \lambda_{c}}
\]
When \( \lambda_{0} = 0.188 \times 10^{-2} \, \mathrm{nm} \)
\[
\frac{K}{E} = 56\%
\]

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Sunlight is incident perpendicularly on the surface of water, with the refractive index of water being $n=1.33$. Find the reflectance $R$ and transmittance $T(R+T=1)$ of the energy.
solution:
According to the Fresnel equations, for normal incidence:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& R=\left(\frac{n-1}{n+1}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{1.33-1}{1.33+1}\right)^{2}=0.02 \\
& T=\frac{4n}{(n+1)^{2}}=\frac{4 \times 1.33}{(1.33+1)^{2}}=0.98
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
Derive the number of photons emitted per square meter of a blackbody within a unit solid angle per micron wavelength interval from the spectral radiance $b_{\lambda}$

$$
n_{\lambda}=\frac{2 c}{\lambda^{4}\left(\mathrm{e}^{h c / \lambda k T}-1\right)}
$$
solution:
Monochromatic radiance

$$
b_{\lambda, T}=n_{\lambda, T} \varepsilon
$$

where $\varepsilon=h \nu=h \frac{c}{\lambda}$ is the photon energy with its corresponding wavelength $\lambda$, and $n_{\lambda, T}$ is the corresponding photon flux density.

According to Planck's blackbody radiation formula, the monochromatic radiance of a blackbody, i.e., the radiative power per square meter, per solid angle, in the wavelength range from $\lambda$ to $\lambda + \Delta \lambda$, along the normal direction is

$$
b_{\lambda, T}=2 h c^{2} \lambda^{-5} \frac{1}{\mathrm{e}^{h c / \lambda k T}-1}
$$

Then the photon flux density is

$$
n_{\lambda, T}=\frac{b_{\lambda, T}}{\varepsilon}=\frac{2 c}{\lambda^{4}} \frac{1}{\mathrm{e}^{h c / \lambda k T}-1}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Light with a wavelength of 200 nm is shone onto the surface of aluminum. It is known that the energy required to remove an electron is 4.2 eV. What is the cutoff wavelength for aluminum?
solution:
The cutoff wavelength (red limit) for aluminum is given by $h \nu_{0} = A$ or $\frac{h c}{\lambda_{0}} = A$:

$$
\lambda_{0}=\frac{h c}{A}=295 \text{ nm}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: If the Sun loses mass at a rate of $1.4 \times 10^{17} \, \mathrm{kg}$ per year, how many years will it take for the Sun's mass to become zero? Given that the Sun's mass is $2.0 \times 10^{30} \, \mathrm{kg}$.
solution:
At this rate of mass consumption, the time required for the Sun's mass to become zero is

$$
\frac{2.0 \times 10^{30}}{1.4 \times 10^{17}} = 1.4 \times 10^{13} \, \mathrm{years}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Solar energy with a radiation flux of $800 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$ is incident on a solar cell plate used to heat water. Assume that the absorptance of the plate for all wavelengths is reduced by half, while the other surfaces are completely insulated. Calculate the maximum temperature of the water.
solution:
When $\alpha^{\prime} = \frac{1}{2} \alpha$,

$$
\frac{T^{\prime}}{T} = \sqrt[4]{\frac{\alpha^{\prime}}{\alpha}}, \quad T^{\prime} = \sqrt[4]{\frac{\alpha^{\prime}}{\alpha}} T = \frac{T}{\sqrt[4]{2}} = 0.84 T
$$

Substituting $T = 341 \mathrm{~K}$, we find $T^{\prime} = 286 \mathrm{~K}$.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
Prove that if the absorption and scattering of light by optical components are neglected, the brightness of the image is only related to the brightness of the object and the refractive indices of the media on the object and image sides, independent of the positions and magnification of the object and image.

Let \( y, \sigma, B, u_0, n \) represent the linear dimension, area, brightness, incident aperture angle, and refractive index on the object side, respectively. Correspondingly, let \( y', \sigma', B', u_0', n' \) be the quantities on the image side.

Based on the above information, prove the following result. The problem will be divided into several parts.

1. Calculate the luminous flux \(\Phi\) entering the pupil.
solution:
Assume the luminous flux entering the pupil is

\[
\Phi = \int B \sigma \cos u \, \mathrm{d} u = \int_{0}^{u_0} B \sigma \cos u \sin u \, \mathrm{d} u \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \, \mathrm{d} \varphi
\]

For a Lambertian radiator, the above expression gives

\[
\Phi = \pi B \sigma \sin^2 u_0 \quad \text{or} \quad B = \frac{\Phi}{\pi \sigma \sin^2 u_0}
\]

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A plane light illuminates the surface of a sphere, where the diameter of the sphere is much larger than the wavelength. Try to express the pressure of light on an absolutely rough (satisfying Lambert's law) sphere in terms of the incident light density.
solution:
From the previous problem, we know that the average momentum of photons leaving the surface of an ideally diffuse reflector is $\frac{1}{2} \frac{h \nu}{c}$. According to Lambert's law, the intensity of scattered light in each direction is proportional to $\cos i$. Therefore, the additional pressure caused by the scattered light is

$$
\Delta F=\frac{1}{2} N h \nu \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} 2 \pi a^{2} \sin i \cdot \cos i \cdot \cos i \cdot \mathrm{~d} i=\frac{1}{3} N h \nu \pi a^{2}=\frac{1}{3} S u
$$

The pressure generated by the incident light $F$ should also be added, so the total pressure is

$$
F^{\prime \prime}=F+\Delta F=\frac{4}{3} S u
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: In a uniform gravitational field, assume the direction $g$ is opposite to the $x$ coordinate. A photon with an initial frequency $\nu_{0}$ is moving in the direction of $x$. Determine the photon's frequency when it reaches $x^{\prime}$.
solution:
Assume the energy of the photon at $x$ is $h \nu$, and at $x+\Delta x$ it is $h(\nu+\Delta \nu)$, with the gravitational force being constant in the range from $x$ to $x+\Delta x$. According to the principle of momentum, the change in the photon's energy is equal to the work done by gravity, that is

$$
h \Delta \nu = \left(-\frac{h \nu g}{c^{2}}\right) \Delta x
$$

or

$$
\frac{\Delta \nu}{\nu} = -\frac{g}{c^{2}} \Delta x
$$

Integrating gives

$$
\nu_{x^{\prime}} = \nu_{0} \exp \left\{-\frac{g x^{\prime}}{c^{2}}\right\}
$$

This means $\nu_{x} < \nu_{0}$, indicating gravitational redshift.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: What is the critical angle for total internal reflection at a water-air interface? Choose the most suitable answer from the following options: \(5^{\circ}, 20^{\circ}, 50^{\circ}\). The refractive index of water is \(n = \frac{4}{3}\), and the refractive index of air is 1.
solution: The critical angle \(i_c\) for total internal reflection can be calculated using the formula \(i_c = \arcsin(1/n)\). By substituting the refractive index of water \(n = \frac{4}{3}\), we find \(i_c = \arcsin(1/(4/3)) \approx 49^{\circ} \approx 50^{\circ}\). Therefore, the most suitable answer is \(50^{\circ}\).

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Above the table, there is a light bulb $L$ with an intensity of 100 cd, which can be considered as an isotropic point light source. The light $L$ can be moved up and down. How should its height be adjusted to maximize the illuminance at point $B$?
solution:
Let the variable distance from the light bulb to point $A$ be $y$, then the distance from $L$ to $B$ is

$$
r = \frac{y}{\sin \theta}
$$

The formula for illuminance is

$$
E = \frac{I}{y^{2}} \cos \theta \sin ^{2} \theta
$$

Taking the derivative, we have

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d} E}{\mathrm{~d} \theta} = \frac{I}{y^{2}}\left(-\sin ^{3} \theta + 2 \sin \theta \cdot \cos ^{2} \theta\right)
$$

Setting $\frac{\mathrm{d} E}{\mathrm{~d} \theta} = 0$, we obtain

$$
\tan \theta = \sqrt{2} = \frac{\overline{AB}}{y}
$$

Thus,

$$
y = \frac{\overline{AB}}{\sqrt{2}} = 0.7 \mathrm{~m}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: In a carbon monoxide (CO) molecule, the bond energy between carbon and oxygen is 11 eV. To photodissociate this molecule using radiation energy, what should be the minimum frequency of the light?
solution:
Given the condition $h \nu \geqslant E$, the minimum frequency is calculated as:

$$
\nu_{\min} = \frac{E}{h} = \frac{11 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19}}{6.6 \times 10^{-34}} = 2.7 \times 10^{15} \, \text{Hz}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A light source and a screen are 100 cm apart, with two possible positions for placing a lens to form an image on the screen. These two positions are 20 cm apart. The object distance and image distance are known to be \( s_{1} = s_{2}^{\prime} = 40 \, \text{cm} \) and \( s_{2} = s_{1}^{\prime} = 60 \, \text{cm} \), respectively. Find the ratio of the light energy received by the lens at the two positions, \( E_{1} / E_{2} \).
solution:
According to the lens formula and conjugate relationship, the ratio of the light energy received by the lens can be calculated through the solid angle relation. The light energy ratio is:

$$
E_{1} / E_{2} = \Omega_{1} / \Omega_{2} = \left(s_{2} / s_{1}\right)^{2}
$$

Substituting the given values:

$$ 
E_{1} / E_{2} = \left(60 / 40\right)^{2} = 2.25
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
A wiggler is an array composed of magnets with alternating polarities arranged along a straight line. The length of a repeating unit in the array is $d$, and there are $N$ such units in total. An electron with a velocity close to the speed of light enters the wiggler with a slight deviation from the wiggler's centerline. Within the wiggler, the electron oscillates due to the magnetic field and emits radiation, with the strongest emission at the fundamental frequency corresponding to a certain wavelength $\lambda$.  
Determine the spectral line width $\Delta \lambda / \lambda$ of the radiation produced by a beam of electrons with a single energy.
solution:
The result is analogous to the principle of multiple beam interference or interference filters, having a spectral resolution given by

$$
\frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda} = \frac{1}{N}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
When sunlight shines directly on the ground, the illuminance is \(1.0 \times 10^{5} \, \mathrm{lx}\). Assuming that the brightness of the Sun is independent of the direction of the light flux and neglecting atmospheric absorption, find the brightness of the Sun. It is known that the radius of Earth's orbit is \(1.5 \times 10^{8} \, \mathrm{km}\) and the diameter of the Sun is \(1.4 \times 10^{6} \, \mathrm{km}\).

Solve using the principle of reciprocity.
solution:
Method Two As shown in the figure, according to the principle of reciprocity, the light flux received by a surface element \(\Delta S^{\prime}\) on the ground from the Sun with brightness \(B\) is equal to the light flux received by the Sun from the surface element \(\Delta S^{\prime}\) with brightness \(B\). That is,

\[
\Delta \Phi = \Delta \Phi^{\prime} = B \Delta S^{\prime} \Delta \Omega^{\prime}
\]

It is known that the illuminance on Earth from the sunlight is

\[
E = \frac{\Delta \Phi}{\Delta S^{\prime}}
\]

Using the Sun's radius and the distance between the Earth and the Sun, the solid angle subtended by the Sun at the Earth can be calculated as

\[
\Delta \Omega^{\prime} \approx \frac{\pi r^{2}}{z^{2}}
\]

Thus,

\[
B = \left(\frac{\Delta \Phi}{\Delta S^{\prime}}\right) \cdot \left(\frac{z^{2}}{\pi r^{2}}\right) = \frac{E z^{2}}{\pi r^{2}}
\]

The conclusion remains unchanged.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
An undulator is an array composed of alternating polarity magnets aligned along a straight line. The length of the repeating unit of the array is $d$, and there are $N$ such units. An electron moving at a velocity close to the speed of light enters the undulator, with its initial velocity slightly deviating from the centerline of the undulator. Within the undulator, the electron is repeatedly deflected by the magnetic field, producing radiation, and radiates most strongly at the fundamental frequency corresponding to a certain wavelength $\lambda$.  
What is the ratio of the forward radiation intensity produced by the entire undulator to the radiation intensity produced by a single unit?

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
Prove that if the absorption and scattering of light by the optical system are ignored, the brightness of the image is only related to the brightness of the object and the refractive indices of the media on the object and image sides, and is independent of the object-image position and magnification.

Let \( y, \sigma, B, u_0, n \) represent the linear dimension, area, brightness, incident aperture angle, and refractive index on the object side, respectively, while \( y', \sigma', B', u_0', n' \) represent the corresponding quantities on the image side.

Using the results from previous proofs, answer the following question:

4. Discuss the relationship between the brightness of the image and the brightness of the object when the refractive indices on the object and image sides are equal.
solution:
That is,

\[
B' = B \left(\frac{n'}{n}\right)^2
\]

If the refractive indices of the media on the object and image sides are equal, then the brightness of the object and the image are equal. The sine condition indicates that if the image is magnified, the aperture of the light beam decreases. Although the total luminous flux from a unit area is reduced, it is concentrated within a smaller aperture, so the luminous flux emitted per unit area within a unit solid angle remains constant.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: The speed of an electron reaches one fifth of the speed of light. Find the de Broglie wavelength of this beam of electrons.
solution:
The mass of the moving electron is given by

$$
m = \frac{m_{0}}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}
$$

where $\beta = \frac{v}{c}$.\
The de Broglie wavelength is

$$
\lambda = \frac{h}{m v} = \frac{h \sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}{m_{0} v} = \frac{h \sqrt{1-(v/c)^{2}}}{m_{0} \times \frac{1}{5} c}
$$

$$
= \frac{5 h}{m_{0} c} \sqrt{1-0.2^{2}} = 0.012 \, \text{nm}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: In a uniform gravitational field, assume the direction $g$ is opposite to the $x$ coordinate. A photon initially with frequency $\nu_{0}$ is moving along the $x$ direction. Determine the initial gravitational force acting on the photon.
solution:
The mass of the photon

$$
m_{p} = \frac{h \nu_{0}}{c^{2}}
$$

The initial gravitational force experienced

$$
F = m_{p} g = \frac{h \nu_{0} g}{c^{2}}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: The nearby lamp emits a conical light with a cone angle of $2 \theta_{0} = 40^{\circ}$. The luminous flux of the lamp is $\Phi = 80 \mathrm{klm}$. Assume the luminous flux is uniformly distributed within the cone. Find the luminous intensity of the lamp.
solution:
The luminous intensity $I$ of an isotropic light source is equal to the ratio of the luminous flux $\Phi$ to the solid angle $\omega$ within which the luminous flux is transmitted, that is,

$$
I = \frac{\Phi}{\omega}
$$

In the diagram, the solid angle element $\mathrm{d} \omega = 2 \pi \sin \theta \, \mathrm{d} \theta$.

When the distance from the light source is $R$, the area of the ring within $\mathrm{d} \theta$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{d} S = 2 \pi R^{2} \sin \theta \, \mathrm{d} \theta \\
& \mathrm{d} \omega = \frac{\mathrm{d} S}{R^{2}} = 2 \pi \sin \theta \, \mathrm{d} \theta
\end{aligned}
$$

The solid angle corresponding to $2 \theta_{0}$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \omega = 2 \pi \int_{0}^{\theta_{0}} \sin \theta \, \mathrm{d} \theta = 2 \pi \left(1 - \cos \theta_{0} \right) = 4 \pi \sin^{2} \left( \frac{\theta_{0}}{2} \right) \\
& I = \frac{\Phi}{\omega} = \frac{80}{4 \pi \sin^{2} 10^{\circ}} = 211 \mathrm{kcd}
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
<image 1>
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: If the speed of light in a stationary liquid is \( c / n(\lambda) \), where \( \lambda \) is the wavelength of light in the stationary liquid, considering dispersion, find the speed of light \( v_{\uparrow} \) in the moving liquid in the first-order approximation.
solution:
Using the previously obtained \( n(\lambda^{\prime}) \), the speed of light can be expressed as:

\[
\frac{c}{n\left(\lambda^{\prime}\right)} \approx \frac{c / n}{1+\lambda \frac{\mathrm{d} n}{\mathrm{~d} \lambda} \cdot \frac{v}{c}} \approx \frac{c}{n} - \lambda \frac{\mathrm{d} n}{\mathrm{~d} \lambda} \cdot \frac{v}{n}
\]

Using the formula for relativistic velocity addition, we find:

\[
\begin{aligned}
v_{\uparrow} &= \frac{\frac{c}{n\left(\lambda^{\prime}\right)}+v}{1+\frac{v}{n\left(\lambda^{\prime}\right) c}} \\
&\approx \left(\frac{c}{n} - \lambda \frac{\mathrm{d} n}{\mathrm{~d} \lambda} \cdot \frac{v}{n} + v \right) \left(1 - \frac{1}{c} \cdot \frac{v}{n}\right) \\
&\approx \frac{c}{n} + v\left(1 - \frac{1}{n^{2}} - \frac{\lambda}{n} \frac{\mathrm{d} n}{\mathrm{~d} \lambda}\right)
\end{aligned}
\]

In the equation, \( v \) is negative if it is towards the light source; it is positive if it is in the same direction as the light.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
A wiggler is an array of alternating magnetic poles aligned along a straight line. The length of the repeating unit in the array is $d$, with a total of $N$ such units. An electron, moving at nearly the speed of light, enters the wiggler. Its initial velocity has a slight deviation from the wiggler's central axis, causing it to repeatedly deflect under the influence of the magnetic field and emit radiation. The radiation is strongest at the fundamental frequency corresponding to a certain wavelength $\lambda$.  
If the electron's speed differs from the speed of light by $1 \times 10^{-6}$, and $d=10 \mathrm{~cm}$, find the wavelength of the radiation produced by the wiggler.
solution:
According to the problem, $v = \left(1 - 1 \times 10^{-6}\right) c$, substituting into the formula we get  

$$
\lambda = d\left(\beta^{-1} - 1\right) = 100 \mathrm{~nm}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A light source emits $S$ units of light energy per unit area per unit time isotropically into a unit solid angle. If the subtended solid angle is the one received by a telescope observing this light source, denoted as $\Omega$, find the product of the image area formed by the objective lens and the solid angle subtended by the objective lens to the image.
solution:
The area of the image $\sigma^{\prime}$ is

$$
\sigma^{\prime} = \Omega f^2
$$

where $f$ is the focal length of the objective lens. The solid angle subtended by the objective lens to the image is

$$
\Omega^{\prime} = \left(\frac{\pi D^2}{4}\right) / f^2
$$

where $D$ is the diameter of the objective lens. Therefore, we have

$$
\sigma^{\prime} \Omega^{\prime} = \Omega f^2 \cdot \left(\frac{\pi D^2}{4}\right) / f^2 = \frac{\pi D^2}{4} \cdot \Omega = A \cdot \Omega
$$

i.e., the product of the image area and the solid angle subtended by the objective lens to the image equals the product of the objective lens area and the solid angle received by the telescope, if the light source is sufficiently large.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: The sun shines on a small circular disk with a cross-sectional area of \( S \), which is at a uniform temperature. The sun is equivalent to a perfect black body at 6000 K with an emissive power of \( H \). The solid angle of the sun with respect to the disk is \( 2 \alpha \). Calculate the equilibrium temperature of the small disk. Suppose the disk transforms into a sphere of the same diameter, calculate the sphere's equilibrium temperature when \( 2 \alpha \) is \( 10^{-2} \,\mathrm{rad} \) and \( 10^{-4} \,\mathrm{rad} \), respectively.
solution:
The emissive power of the sun is \( H = \sigma T_{0}^{4} \), where \( \sigma \) is the Stefan-Boltzmann constant, \( \sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{-8} \,\mathrm{W/m^{2} \cdot K^{4}} \).

The radius of the sun is \( R \), so the total radiation power is
\[
\Phi = 4 \pi R^{2} H
\]

At a distance \( r \) from the sun, the radiation received by a cross-sectional area \( S \) is
\[
S \alpha^{2} \sigma T_{0}^{4}
\]

The disk is at temperature \( T^{\prime} \) with an emissive power of \( H^{\prime} = \sigma T^{\prime 4} \).

For a small sphere with radius \( \rho \), the effective illuminated area is \( \pi \rho^{2} \), and the radiating area is \( 4 \pi \rho^{2} \). Thus, at thermal equilibrium, we have:
\[
\pi \rho^{2} \alpha^{2} \sigma T_{0}^{4} = 4 \pi \rho^{2} \sigma T^{\prime 4}
\]

Solving, we find
\[
T^{\prime} = \sqrt{\alpha} \frac{T_{0}}{\sqrt{2}}
\]

For \( \alpha = 0.5 \times 10^{-2} \), we have
\[
T_{a}^{*} = 300\,\mathrm{K}
\]

For \( \alpha = 0.5 \times 10^{-4} \), we have
\[
T_{b}^{*} = 30\,\mathrm{K}
\]

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
Find the expression for the maximum apparent transverse velocity \((v_{\perp}^{\prime})_{max}\) corresponding to a given value of \(\beta\).

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline
\begin{tabular}{c}
Time \\[0pt]
[days] \\

$\theta_{2}$ \\[0pt]

\hline
0 & 0.139 & 0.076 \\
\hline
7 & 0.253 & 0.139 \\
\hline

\hline

solution:
Differentiating equation (11), we have:

\[
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} \phi}\left(\frac{v_{\perp}^{\prime}}{c}\right)=\beta(\cos \phi-\beta) /(1-\beta \cos \phi)^{2}
\]

At \(\phi=\phi_{m}\):

\[
\cos \phi_{m}=\beta ; \phi_{m}=\arccos \beta
\]

Differentiating again:

\[
\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}}{\mathrm{~d} \phi^{2}}\left(\frac{w_{\perp}^{\prime}}{c}\right) \big|_{\phi_{m}}=-\frac{\beta \sin \phi_{m}}{\left(1-\beta^{2}\right)^{2}}<0
\]

The maximum apparent transverse velocity is:

\]

\(\text { As } \beta \rightarrow 1 \):

\[
\left(v_{\perp}^{\prime}\right)_{\text {max }} \rightarrow \infty ; \phi_{m} \rightarrow 0
\]

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
In a vacuum chamber, a collimated beam of $\mathrm{Na}^{23}$ atoms (obtained by evaporating a solid sample at a high temperature of $10^{3} \mathrm{~K}$) is irradiated by a high-intensity laser. The laser frequency is selected so that sodium atoms with a velocity $v_{0}$ can resonantly absorb photons from the laser.

(5) To decelerate atoms with an initial velocity $v_{0}$ moving in a straight line to almost zero velocity in the manner described in part 1, how many absorption events are needed?
solution:
If each absorption event changes the atom's velocity by approximately $\Delta v_{1} \approx -\frac{E}{mc}$, to reduce the velocity from $v_{0}$ to nearly zero requires $N$ absorption events, taking a total time of $\Delta t$. Here,

$$
N = \frac{v_{0}}{\left|\Delta v_{1}\right|} \approx \frac{mc v_{0}}{E} = 3.6 \times 10^{4} \text{ events }
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: The focal length of a lens is $f=0.50 \, \mathrm{m}$, and the diameter of the lens is $d=0.20 \, \mathrm{m}$. The diameter of the Sun is known to be $D=1.4 \times 10^{6} \, \mathrm{km}$, the distance between the Earth and the Sun is $z=1.5 \times 10^{8} \, \mathrm{km}$, and the radiance of the Sun is $B=2.0 \times 10^{7} \, \mathrm{W} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{-2} \cdot \mathrm{sr}^{-1}$. Please calculate the area of the Sun's image at the focal point, as well as the power density of light at the focal point.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A filament with a length of $l = 10 \mathrm{~cm}$ and a diameter of $d = 0.03 \mathrm{~mm}$ consumes power $P = 25 \mathrm{~W}$, of which $P_{1} = 2 \mathrm{~W}$ is lost due to thermal conduction. Find the wavelength $\lambda_{m}$ corresponding to the peak of the filament's radiation. The filament can be considered as a black body.
solution:
Wien's displacement law is:

\[
T \lambda_{m} = b = 2.9 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m} \cdot \mathrm{~K}
\]

Therefore:

\[
\lambda_{m} = \frac{b}{T}
\]

The radiated power of the filament is:

\[
P - P_{1} = \pi d l \sigma T^{4}
\]

Solving for the wavelength:

\[
\lambda_{m} = \frac{b}{T} = b \left(\frac{\pi d l \sigma}{P - P_{1}}\right)^{-1/4}
\]

Where $\sigma$ is the Stefan-Boltzmann constant. Substituting the relevant values gives:

\[
\lambda_{m} = 1.1 \mu \mathrm{~m}
\]

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
The optical system is a camera. Given that the luminous flux is:

$$
\Phi' = \pi B \sigma' \sin^2 u_0'
$$

derive the formula for the illuminance on the film.
solution:
The illuminance on the image plane (i.e., the film) is given by

$$
E = \frac{\Phi'}{\sigma'} = \pi B' \sin^2 u_0' = \pi B \left(\frac{n'}{n}\right)^2 \sin^2 u_0' = \pi B \frac{\sin^2 u_0}{V^2}
$$

where $V^2 = \sigma' / \sigma$, and $V$ is the lateral magnification. Under paraxial conditions,

$$
E = \pi B \left(\frac{n'}{n}\right)^2 u_0^2 = \frac{\pi B u_0^2}{V^2}
$$

Here, the sine condition $n y \sin u_0 = n' y' \sin u_0'$ is applied.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: At the edge of the Earth's atmosphere, the solar radiance value is $B = 2.0 \times 10^{7} \, \mathrm{W} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{-2} \cdot \mathrm{sr}^{-1}$. Determine the power of the light on a unit area directly facing the Sun at that location. The diameter of the Sun is given as $D = 1.4 \times 10^{6} \, \mathrm{km}$, and the Earth-Sun distance is $z = 1.5 \times 10^{8} \, \mathrm{km}$. ($\mathrm{sr}$ is the unit of solid angle).
solution:
$B$ represents the radiative power per unit area and per unit solid angle on the Sun (considered as a Lambertian emitter, a luminous disk with an equivalent diameter $D$). The solid angle subtended by the Sun from a unit area on Earth is $\Omega = \frac{1 \, \mathrm{m}^{2}}{z^{2}} = \frac{1}{(1.5 \times 10^{11})^{2}}$. Therefore, the solar constant, which is the solar power received by a unit area above the Earth's atmosphere, is calculated as

$$
S = B \cdot \frac{\pi D^{2}}{4} \cdot \Omega = \frac{B \pi}{4} \left(\frac{D}{z}\right)^{2} = \frac{2.0 \pi \times 10^{7}}{4} \left(\frac{1.4 \times 10^{9}}{1.5 \times 10^{11}}\right)^{2} = 1.4 \times 10^{3} \, \mathrm{W} \cdot \mathrm{m}^{-2}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Four black parallel metal plates are placed with a vacuum in between. One plate at each end is maintained at \( 100^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) and \( 10^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \), respectively. Calculate the energy flow between the plates and compare it to the situation where the two middle plates are removed.
solution:
At thermal equilibrium, the energy flow density between each plate is equal, i.e.,

\[ \dot{Q} = \sigma (T_{1}^{4} - T_{2}^{4}) = \sigma (T_{2}^{4} - T_{3}^{4}) = \sigma (T_{3}^{4} - T_{4}^{4}) \]

This results in

\[ \dot{Q} = \frac{1}{3} \sigma (T_{1}^{4} - T_{4}^{4}) \]

When plates 2 and 3 are removed, the energy flow density between plate 1 and plate 4 is

\[
\begin{gathered}
\dot{Q}_{0} = \sigma (T_{1}^{4} - T_{4}^{4}) \\
\dot{Q} / \dot{Q}_{0} = \frac{1}{3}
\end{gathered}
\]

In general, inserting \( n \) plates reduces the energy flow density to \( \frac{1}{n+1} \) of the original.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: If the speed of light in a stationary liquid is given by \( c / n(\lambda) \), where \( \lambda \) is the wavelength of light in the stationary liquid, consider the dispersion effects and find, in the first-order approximation, the wavelength \( \lambda^{\prime} \) in the reference frame moving with the liquid. Also, derive the expression for \( n(\lambda^{\prime}) \).

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A long filament is placed inside a black metal cylinder with an outer surface area of \( S = 150 \text{ cm}^2 \), consuming power \( P = 25 \text{ W} \), of which \( P_1 = 2 \text{ W} \) is lost due to heat conduction. Assuming the heat conduction loss remains constant, determine the wavelength \(\lambda_{m}^{\prime}\) corresponding to the maximum radiation of the cylinder. The filament can be considered as a black body.
solution:
If the lamp is placed inside the cylinder, the power radiated by the cylinder is given by:

\[
S \sigma T^{4} = P - P_{1}
\]

Therefore:

\[
T = \left(\frac{P - P_{1}}{\sigma S}\right)^{1/4}
\]

The wavelength is:

\[
\lambda_{m}^{\prime} = \frac{b}{T} = b \left(\frac{S \sigma}{P - P_{1}}\right)^{1/4} = 7.2 \mu \text{m}
\]

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
The power of solar radiation received per unit area when Earth directly faces the sun is \( e = 1.35 \, \mathrm{kW/m}^2 \). The distance between the Earth and the sun is \( r_{1} = 1.50 \times 10^{8} \, \mathrm{km} \), and the radius of the sun is \( r_{2} = 6.95 \times 10^{5} \, \mathrm{km} \). Assuming the sun is a perfect blackbody, find:

(3) The surface temperature of the sun.
solution:
(3) The emissive power (i.e., surface emissive power) \( R \) of the sun is given by
$$
R = \frac{\psi}{S} = \frac{4 \pi r_{1}^{2} e}{4 \pi r_{2}^{2}} = e\left(\frac{r_{1}}{r_{2}}\right)^{2}
$$
According to Stefan's law, \( R = \sigma T^{4} \), hence
$$
T = \sqrt[4]{\frac{R}{\sigma}} = \sqrt[4]{\frac{e}{\sigma}\left(\frac{r_{1}}{r_{2}}\right)^{2}} = 5773 \, \mathrm{K}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A photon, with a frequency of $f$ in the rest frame of a target electron, is observed to be scattered in the direction of $-90^{\circ}$ with a frequency of $f^{\prime}$. Express the total energy of the electron in terms of $f$, $f^{\prime}$, and the electron mass $m$.
solution:
The total energy of the electron is

$$
E = \sqrt{m^{2} c^{4} + P_{c}^{2} c^{2}} = \sqrt{m^{2} c^{4} + \left(p_{f}^{2} + p_{f^{\prime}}^{2}\right) c^{2}}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
Discuss the standing wave modes of electromagnetic waves within a cavity. Assume the cavity is a rectangular prism with side lengths \(L_{1}, L_{2}\), and \(L_{3}\), and has a volume \(V\). The cavity and its walls are in thermal equilibrium at an absolute temperature \(T\), and there is a steady radiation field within the cavity. The plane electromagnetic wave is given by

\[
\Phi(\boldsymbol{r}; t) = A \exp [\mathrm{i}(\omega t - \boldsymbol{k} \cdot \boldsymbol{r})]
\]

Find the condition for the standing wave and the relationship with the wave vector.
solution:
Assume the components of the wave vector \(\boldsymbol{k}\) in a three-dimensional Cartesian coordinate system are \(k_{x}, k_{y}\), and \(k_{z}\), i.e.,

\[
k \cdot r = k_{x} x + k_{y} y + k_{z} z 
\]

The condition for forming a standing wave is

\[
\left\{
\begin{array}{l}
m_{1} = \frac{2 L_{1} \cos \alpha}{\lambda} \\
m_{2} = \frac{2 L_{2} \cos \beta}{\lambda} \\
m_{3} = \frac{2 L_{3} \cos \gamma}{\lambda}
\end{array}
\right.
\]

where \(m_{1}, m_{2}\), and \(m_{3}\) are integers or zero:

\[
m_{1}, m_{2}, m_{3} = 0,1,2, \ldots
\]

Combining these equations, we obtain

\[
k_{x} = m_{1} \frac{\pi}{L_{1}}, \quad k_{y} = m_{2} \frac{\pi}{L_{2}}, \quad k_{z} = m_{3} \frac{\pi}{L_{3}}
\]

Hence,

\[
k^{2} = k_{x}^{2} + k_{y}^{2} + k_{z}^{2} = \pi^{2} \left( \frac{m_{1}^{2}}{L_{1}^{2}} + \frac{m_{2}^{2}}{L_{2}^{2}} + \frac{m_{3}^{2}}{L_{3}^{2}} \right)
\]

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A gas is composed of molecules with two non-degenerate energy levels $E_{1}$ and $E_{2}$ ($E_{1} < E_{2}$), and is in equilibrium. Consider stimulated emission, and express the absorption coefficient $\chi(T)$ of the gas at temperature $T$ in terms of the absorption coefficient at $T=0$, $\chi_{0}$. Investigate the limit where $kT \ll h\nu = E_{2} - E_{1}$.
solution:
Let the number of gas molecules in the energy levels $E_{1}$ and $E_{2}$ be $N_{1}$ and $N_{2}$, respectively. In thermal equilibrium, the probability of absorption equals the probability of emission. Thus, the absorption coefficient $\chi$ is proportional to $\left(N_{2} - N_{1}\right)$. According to the Boltzmann distribution:

$$
N_{2} = N_{1} e^{-\left(E_{2} - E_{1}\right) / kT} = N_{1} e^{-h\nu / kT}
$$

Therefore,

$$
N_{1} - N_{2} = N_{1} \left[1 - e^{-h\nu / kT}\right]
$$

which gives

$$
\chi(T) = \chi_{0} \left[1 - e^{-h\nu / kT}\right]
$$

If $h\nu / kT \gg 1$, then $\chi(T) = \chi_{0}$. This occurs in the optical range. For $5000 \ \AA, T = 1500 \ \mathrm{K}$, $h\nu / kT \approx 20$.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
A convex lens with a $F = 2$ focuses sunlight through a small aperture into a box with blackened inner walls. Ignoring the absorption of light by the atmosphere and the lens, assume the surface temperature of the sun is $T_{c} = 6000 \mathrm{~K}$. The box is adiabatic to the exterior except for radiation energy through the small hole.

1. Calculate the power received by the lens and the area of the solar image. It is known that the ratio of the lens's focal length to its diameter is 2, i.e.:

   $$
   F = \frac{f}{d} = 2
   $$

   Endeavor to compute these values using appropriate physical formulas.
solution:
Let $R_{c}$ denote the solar radius, and $R$ be the distance from the Earth to the sun. Then the power received by the lens is:

$$
\sigma T_{c}^{4}\left(\frac{R_{c}}{R}\right)^{2} \cdot \frac{\pi d^{2}}{4}
$$

The area of the solar image is:

$$
\pi r^{2} = \pi \left(\frac{R_{c} \cdot f}{R}\right)^{2}
$$

This applies the relation $\frac{r}{R_{c}} = \frac{f}{R}$.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Determine the radiation pressure at the Earth's surface using the solar constant.
solution:
Given

$$
E = p \cdot c, \quad \frac{\mathrm{d}E}{\mathrm{d}t} = c \cdot \frac{\mathrm{d}p}{\mathrm{d}t}
$$

The pressure $P$ is equal to the rate of change of momentum per unit area.

$$
P = \frac{\mathrm{d}p}{\mathrm{d}t} = \frac{1}{c} \cdot \frac{\mathrm{d}E}{\mathrm{d}t} = \frac{1}{3 \times 10^8 \, \mathrm{m/s}} \cdot 1.4 \times 10^3 \, \mathrm{J/(m^2 \cdot s)} \approx 0.5 \times 10^{-5} \, \mathrm{N/m^2}
$$

Therefore, the radiation pressure $P = 0.5 \times 10^{-5} \, \mathrm{N/m^2}$.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A light source emits $S$ units of light energy isotropically into a unit solid angle per unit time per unit area. If the solid angle is the one subtended by a telescope observing it, receiving the solid angle $\Omega$. Determine the amount of light energy entering the telescope per second.
solution:
According to the problem, the brightness of the light source is $S$. The light flux entering the telescope is

$$
\Phi = \int S \mathrm{~d} \Sigma \mathrm{~d} \Sigma^{\prime} \frac{\cos \theta \cdot \cos \theta^{\prime}}{r^2}
$$

where $\mathrm{d} \Sigma$ is an area element on the light source, $\mathrm{d} \Sigma^{\prime}$ is an area element of the telescope lens, $r$ is the distance from the light source to the telescope, $\theta$ is the angle between the light ray and the normal to the area element of the light source, and $\theta^{\prime}$ is the angle between the light ray and the normal to the telescope surface. Assuming the telescope is directly facing the light source, we have $\theta^{\prime} = 0$, thus $\cos \theta^{\prime} = 1$.

The solid angle subtended by the light source for the telescope is

$$
\int \frac{\cos \theta}{r^2} \mathrm{~d} \Sigma = \Omega
$$

where $\Omega$ is the solid angle received by the telescope, so only the light within $\Omega$ can enter the telescope. Let $A$ be the area of the telescope. Therefore, the light flux entering the telescope is

$$
\Phi = S \Omega A
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A cylindrical fluorescent lamp with a diameter of \( d = 2.5 \, \text{cm} \) and length \( l = 40 \, \text{cm} \) causes an illumination of \( E = 21 \, \text{lx} \) at a distance of \( r = 5 \, \text{m} \) perpendicular to the axis of the lamp. Find the luminance \( B \) of the lamp, given that the luminous intensity \( I = 525 \, \text{cd} \).
solution:
Luminance:

$$
B = \frac{I}{\sigma}
$$

where \(\sigma\) is the area of the projection of the elongated light source perpendicular to the direction of observation. \(\sigma = l \cdot d\); substituting in gives:

$$
B = \frac{525}{0.025 \times 0.4} = 5.25 \times 10^{3} \, \text{cd/m}^{2}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Assume that X-rays with a wavelength of \( 0.100 \, \mathrm{nm} \) collide with free electrons. Calculate the Compton wavelength shift for this wavelength of light when observing the scattered rays in a direction that forms a \( 90^\circ \) angle with the incident direction.
solution:
The formula for the Compton wavelength shift is
\[
\Delta \lambda = 2 \lambda_{c} \sin^{2}(\theta / 2)
\]
which is independent of the incident light wavelength.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Four black parallel metal plates are placed in a vacuum. One of the plates at the end is maintained at \( 100^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \), and the other at the opposite end is at \( 10^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \). Find the temperatures of the two plates in the middle.
solution:
The four plates are arranged as shown, with the two middle plates exchanging energy through absorption and radiation, eventually reaching equilibrium. At thermal equilibrium, the energy flow density between any two adjacent plates is equal. According to the Stefan-Boltzmann law of black body radiation, the energy radiated per unit area per unit time is given by:

\[ R = \sigma T^{4} \]

For plate 2, the energy flow density radiated outwards on its left side is \( \sigma T_{2}^{4} \), while it absorbs the energy flow density \( \sigma T_{1}^{4}, \, T_{1} > T_{2} \) radiated by plate 1. Therefore, the net increase in energy flow density on the left side is:

\[ \dot{Q}_{2 \text{left}} = \sigma (T_{1}^{4} - T_{2}^{4}) \]

Similarly, the net increase in energy flow density on its right side is:

\[ \dot{Q}_{2 \text{right}} = \sigma (T_{3}^{4} - T_{2}^{4}) \]

At thermal equilibrium, the following condition holds:

\[ \dot{Q}_{2 \text{left}} + \dot{Q}_{2 \text{right}} = 0 \]

Thus,

\[ T_{1}^{4} + T_{3}^{4} - T_{2}^{4} - T_{2}^{4} = 0 \]

or

\[ T_{2}^{4} = \frac{1}{2}(T_{1}^{4} + T_{3}^{4}) \]

Repeating the discussion for plate 3 gives:

\[ T_{3}^{4} = \frac{1}{2}(T_{2}^{4} + T_{4}^{4}) \]

From these two equations we obtain:

\[
\begin{aligned}
& T_{2} = \sqrt[4]{\frac{2T_{1}^{4} + T_{4}^{4}}{3}} = 350 \, \mathrm{K} = 77^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\
& T_{3} = \sqrt[4]{\frac{2T_{4}^{4} + T_{1}^{4}}{3}} = 322 \, \mathrm{K} = 49^{\circ} \mathrm{C}
\end{aligned}
\]

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: When the wavelength of the incident light is changed, the stopping voltage of a certain photoelectric cathode becomes $1.43 \, \mathrm{V}$. Find the wavelength of the light at this time.
solution:
For the case of another material, use Einstein's photoelectric effect equation

$$
e V_{0}^{\prime} = h \nu^{\prime} - A
$$

Using the work function $A$ obtained above, calculate the wavelength $\lambda^{\prime}$ of the incident light at this time using the following system of equations:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& e V_{0}^{\prime} - e V_{0} = h \nu^{\prime} - h \nu = h c \left( \frac{1}{\lambda^{\prime}} - \frac{1}{\lambda} \right) \\
& \frac{1}{\lambda^{\prime}} = \frac{e ( V_{0}^{\prime} - V_{0} )}{h c} + \frac{1}{\lambda} \\
& \lambda^{\prime} = 382 \, \mathrm{nm}
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A photon with a wavelength of \(0.3 \, \mu \mathrm{m}\) has a wavelength uncertainty of \(10^{-4}\). Determine the uncertainty in the position of this photon.
solution:
The momentum of the photon \(p = \frac{h}{\lambda}\), and the momentum uncertainty \(\left|\frac{\Delta p}{p}\right| = \left|\frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda}\right|\). According to the uncertainty principle \(\Delta x \cdot \Delta p \sim \frac{h}{2 \pi}\). Therefore, the uncertainty in position is

\[
\Delta x = \frac{h}{2 \pi} \frac{1}{\Delta p} = \frac{h}{2 \pi} \frac{1}{p \frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda}} = \frac{\lambda}{2 \pi}\left(\frac{\lambda}{\Delta \lambda}\right) = 0.5 \, \mathrm{mm}
\]

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A photoelectric cathode emits photoelectrons with a stopping voltage of $0.71 \, \mathrm{V}$ for light of wavelength $\lambda = 491 \, \mathrm{nm}$. Calculate the work function $A$ of the material in the photoelectric effect process.
solution:
Einstein's photoelectric equation is

$$
e V_{0} = h \nu - A
$$

where $e$ is the elementary charge of the electron, $V_{0} = 0.71 \, \mathrm{V}$ is the stopping voltage, and $h \nu = \frac{h c}{\lambda}$ is the energy of the incident photon. Here, the wavelength is $\lambda = 491 \, \mathrm{nm}$.

Calculate the work function $A$ of the material.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Assuming gamma rays with a wavelength of \( 0.188 \times 10^{-2} \, \mathrm{nm} \) obtained from a cesium \( \mathrm{Cs}^{137} \) sample collide with a free electron, determine the Compton wavelength shift for the light observed scattered at an angle of \( 90^{\circ} \) from the direction of incidence.
solution:
The formula for the Compton wavelength shift is
\[
\Delta \lambda = 2 \lambda_{c} \sin^{2}(\theta / 2)
\]
which is independent of the wavelength of the incident light.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: In a Compton scattering experiment, an X-ray photon undergoes an elastic collision with a stationary electron. Write the energy conservation equation, with the electron's momentum being \(mv\), the scattered light frequency as \(\nu'\), and making an angle \(\theta\) with the incident light.
solution:
The energy conservation equation is:
\[
h \nu + m_0 c^2 = h \nu' + m c^2
\]

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: In Compton scattering, find the ratio of the kinetic energy \( K \) of the recoil electron to the energy \( E \) of the incident photon. Express this in terms of the incident wavelength \(\lambda_{0}\), the scattered wavelength \(\lambda'\), and the scattering angle \(\theta\). Hint: Calculate the ratio of the energy difference of the photon to the incident energy.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Consider a stationary reference frame $X$ and a moving medium $X'$, where $X'$ moves with a speed $V$ relative to $X$. The speed of light in the laboratory reference frame (in still water) is $\frac{c}{n}$. Find the propagation speed $u$ of light in $X'$, neglecting small quantities.
solution:
Here, $\frac{\mathrm{d}x}{\mathrm{d}t} = \frac{c}{n}$ represents the speed of light in the laboratory reference frame (in still water). Substituting and neglecting small quantities, we obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
u & = \frac{\frac{c}{n} - V}{1 - \frac{V}{c n}} \approx \left( \frac{c}{n} - V \right) \left( 1 + \frac{V}{c n} \right) \\
  & = \frac{c}{n} - V + \frac{V}{n^2} - \frac{V^2}{c n} \approx \frac{c}{n} - V \left( 1 - \frac{1}{n^2} \right)
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
The Planck's black body radiation formula gives the energy distribution of black body radiation:

$$
r_{\lambda, T} \mathrm{~d} \lambda = \frac{2 \pi h c^{2}}{\lambda^{5}} \frac{1}{\mathrm{e}^{h c / \lambda k T} - 1} \mathrm{~d} \lambda
$$

This represents the radiation energy of a black body at absolute temperature $T$ within the wavelength range from $\lambda$ to $\lambda + \mathrm{d} \lambda$. By integrating over all wavelengths, we obtain the total radiative power $R$:

$$
R = \int_{0}^{\infty} r_{\lambda, T} \mathrm{~d} \lambda = \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{2 \pi h c^{2}}{\lambda^{5}} \frac{\mathrm{~d} \lambda}{\mathrm{e}^{h c / \lambda k T} - 1}
$$

Substitute $x = \frac{h c}{\lambda k T}$ and perform an appropriate change of variables to solve this integral.
solution:
Let $x = \frac{h c}{\lambda k T}$, then

$$
\mathrm{d} x = -\frac{h c}{\lambda^2 k T} \mathrm{~d} \lambda = -\frac{k T}{h c} x^{2} \mathrm{~d} \lambda
$$

Thus,

$$
\begin{aligned}
R & = \int_{0}^{\infty} \left(\frac{h c}{\lambda k T}\right)^{5} 2 \pi h c^{2} \left(\frac{k T}{h c}\right)^{5} \frac{1}{\mathrm{e}^{h c/\lambda k T} - 1} \mathrm{~d} \lambda \\
& = -\int_{\infty}^{0} x^{5} 2 \pi h c^{2} \left(\frac{k T}{h c}\right)^{5} \frac{1}{\mathrm{e}^{x} - 1} \frac{h c}{k T x^{2}} \mathrm{~d} x \\
& = \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{2 \pi k^{4} T^{4}}{h^{3} c^{2}} \frac{x^{3}}{\mathrm{e}^{x} - 1} \mathrm{~d} x
\end{aligned}
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Assume a stationary reference frame $X$, and a moving medium $X'$ with a velocity $V$ relative to $X$. Determine the speed of light $u$ in $X'$.
solution:
According to the Lorentz transformation, in the $X'$ reference frame, the coordinates and time are:

$$
x' = \frac{x - V t}{\sqrt{1 - \frac{V^2}{c^2}}}, \quad t' = \frac{t - \left( \frac{V}{c^2} \right) x}{\sqrt{1 - \frac{V^2}{c^2}}}
$$

Differentiating both equations gives:

$$
\mathrm{d}x' = \frac{\mathrm{d}x - V \mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{1 - \frac{V^2}{c^2}}}, \quad \mathrm{d}t' = \frac{\mathrm{d}t - \frac{V}{c^2} \mathrm{d}x}{\sqrt{1 - \frac{V^2}{c^2}}}
$$

Dividing these two expressions gives the speed of light in $X'$:

$$
u = \frac{\mathrm{d}x'}{\mathrm{d}t'} = \frac{\mathrm{d}x - V \mathrm{d}t}{\mathrm{d}t - \frac{V}{c^2} \mathrm{d}x} = \frac{\frac{\mathrm{d}x}{\mathrm{d}t} - V}{1 - \frac{V}{c^2} \frac{\mathrm{d}x}{\mathrm{d}t}}
$$

In this formula, $\left(1 - \frac{1}{n^2}\right)$ is known as the Fresnel drag coefficient (also known as the Fresnel drag or drift coefficient). This was experimentally confirmed by Fizeau (1851), Michelson and Morley (1886), and Zeeman (1914) using interference methods. Interested readers can refer to additional resources, such as the "Basic Concepts in Relativity and Early Quantum Theory" by R. Resnick, translated by the Physics Department of Shanghai Normal University, "Optics" (Volume II) by L. Berg, translated by Yang Jiasun and Zhang Zhixie, and "Optics" edited by Mu Guoguang and Zhan Yuanling, proofread by Shen Shouchun.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Assuming that the radar receives signals reflected by a moving object at frequency $\omega^{\prime}$, determine the "carrier frequency" $\omega_{\mathrm{M}}$ of the signal received by the radar in frame $K$.
solution:
Considering that in frame $K^{\prime}$, the radar moves relative to the object at speed $(-v)$, we then transform back to frame $K$. In frame $K$, the frequency of the reflected signal received by the radar is

\[
\omega_{\mathrm{M}} = \omega^{\prime} \frac{1 + \beta \cos \psi^{\prime}}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} = \omega \cdot \frac{1 - \beta \cos \varphi}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} \cdot \frac{1 + \beta \cos \psi^{\prime}}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} \tag{5}
\]

Using formula (4) and the equation $\psi = \pi + \varphi$, we obtain

\[
\omega_{\mathrm{M}} = \omega \frac{1 - \beta \cos \varphi}{1 + \beta \cos \varphi} \tag{6}
\]

Note that when $\varphi = \frac{\pi}{2}$, i.e., when the object moves perpendicular to the vector pointing from the radar to the object, there will be no change in the frequency of the reflected signal (as received by the same radar), regardless of circumstances.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: An undulator is an array of magnets with alternating polarity arranged along a straight line. The length of one repeating unit of the array is \(d\), and there are \(N\) such units. An electron with a speed close to the speed of light enters the undulator with a slight deviation from the centerline. Under the influence of the magnetic field within the undulator, the electron repeatedly deflects, producing radiation, and emits most strongly at a fundamental frequency corresponding to a certain wavelength \(\lambda\). Determine the wavelength based on the condition for constructive interference of forward radiation from adjacent units.
solution:
The time for the electron beam to travel one period \(d\) is \(\Delta t = \frac{d}{v}\). During the interval \(\Delta t\), the radiation produced at the position of the preceding magnet has advanced a small distance \(\Delta s = c \Delta t - d\) beyond the subsequent magnet on the same side. At this moment, the electron just reaches the N-pole of the subsequent magnet and emits radiation. For these two radiations to constructively interfere, we must have \(\Delta s = n\lambda\), where for the fundamental frequency, \(n=1\). Thus,

\[
\begin{aligned}
& c \Delta t - d = \lambda \\
& \lambda = d\left(\frac{c}{v} - 1\right) = d\left(\beta^{-1} - 1\right)
\end{aligned}
\]

Now consider the radiation from the electron at the N-pole on the opposite side. The time for the electron to travel between two adjacent magnets (distance \(\frac{d}{2}\)) is \(\frac{1}{2} \Delta t\). Based on the discussion above, the radiation at the alternating N-pole differs by \(\pi\). However, since radiation is proportional to acceleration, and from the diagram, the curvature of the electron's trajectory is greatest at alternating N-poles with opposite acceleration directions (reverse sign), this introduces an additional phase difference of \(\pi\). As a result, the radiation at these two locations is in phase and constructively interferes. Therefore, the above equation is still valid.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: Sunlight is incident perpendicularly on the water surface, with the refractive index of water being $n=1.33$. If the power density of the incident light is $1.4 \mathrm{~kW} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$, find the pressure exerted by the incident light on the water surface.
solution:
According to the photon theory, light pressure is the result of photons transferring momentum to an object. Considering that the direction of light changes upon reflection, the momentum change is greater than the momentum of the incident light. Therefore, the light pressure is

$$
p=(1+R) \frac{W}{c}=1.02 \frac{1.4 \times 10^{3}}{3 \times 10^{8}}=0.48 \times 10^{-5} \left(\mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\right)
$$

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A plane wave is incident on the surface of a sphere, where the sphere's diameter is much larger than the wavelength. Express the pressure of the light on a perfectly reflecting sphere in terms of the incident light intensity. For generality, let the surface reflectance be $r$.
solution:
Figure 2: The incident energy flux in the incident direction loses $r u \cos (2 \alpha)$, so the force on $\mathrm{d} S$ in the incident direction is

$$
\mathrm{d} F^{\prime}=u \mathrm{~d} S \cos i-r u \mathrm{~d} S \cos (2 \alpha) \cdot \cos i
$$

and

$$
i-\alpha=\frac{\pi}{2}
$$

so

$$
\begin{aligned}
\cos 2 \alpha & =2 \cos ^{2} \alpha-1=2 \sin ^{2}\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-i\right)-1 \\
& =2 \sin ^{2} i-1
\end{aligned}
$$

The total force on the sphere is

$$
F^{\prime}=\int \mathrm{d} F^{\prime}=\int u \mathrm{~d} S \cdot \cos i-r u \int \cos i\left(2 \sin ^{2} i-1\right) \mathrm{d} S
$$

The first term in the equation is the solution to part (1): $Su$. The second term in the equation is

$$
r u \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} 2 \pi a^{2} \sin i \cos i\left(2 \sin ^{2} i-1\right) \mathrm{d} i=0
$$

Thus, whether the sphere's surface is fully reflective or partially reflective, the light pressure it experiences is the same as that for a perfect black body.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A radar with an operating frequency of $\omega$ (signal "carrier frequency") illuminates an object moving with velocity $v$ in any direction relative to the radar. Considering the Doppler effect, determine the radiation frequency $\omega^{\prime}$ in the coordinate system $K^{\prime}$ due to the Doppler effect.
solution:
Let $K$ and $K^{\prime}$ denote the coordinate systems, where the radar is stationary in $K$ and the object is stationary in $K^{\prime}$. Choose the $x$ and $x^{\prime}$ axes to be parallel to each other and also parallel to the direction of the velocity of the object in $K$ (as shown in the figure). The radar's radiation is incident on the object and reflected. In $K^{\prime}$, due to the Doppler effect, its radiation frequency is given by

\[
\omega^{\prime} = \omega \frac{1-\beta \cos \varphi}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}} \tag{1}
\]

where $\beta = \frac{v}{c}$, and $\varphi$ is the angle between the $x$ axis in $K$ and the direction towards the object.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem:
A disk with an area of $1 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}$ emits monochromatic light uniformly and isotropically. The brightness is $1 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \cdot \mathrm{sr}$.  
(1) Determine the rate of energy emitted by this disk surface.
solution:
As given in the problem, the brightness $B=1 \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{cm}^{2} \cdot \mathrm{sr}$. The radiative flux is  
\[  
\Phi=B S \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \mathrm{~d} \varphi \int_{0}^{\pi} \sin \theta \cdot \cos \theta \cdot \mathrm{d} \theta=\pi B S=3.14 \mathrm{~W}  
\]  
In this equation, $\theta$ is the angle between the light and the normal to the surface of the light source, and $S$ is the area of the light source.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A stationary fish in a fish tank observes a monochromatic plane wave light source directly above the water surface with a frequency of $\nu$. If water is added from the top "layer by layer," causing the water surface to rise at a rate of $v=\frac{\mathrm{d} h}{\mathrm{d} t}$, determine the change in frequency of the light observed by the fish. Assume the refractive index of the water is $n$.
solution:
As the water surface rises, the optical path from the light source to the fish increases at a rate of $(n-1) \frac{\mathrm{d} h}{\mathrm{d} t}$. This is equivalent to the light source moving away from the observer—the fish—at this rate. The observed redshift in the light has a shift amount of

$$
-\frac{\Delta \nu}{\nu} = \frac{v}{c} = \frac{n-1}{c} \frac{\mathrm{d} h}{\mathrm{d} t}
$$

Since $n>1$, it follows that $\Delta \nu<0, \Delta \lambda>0$. This is based on the same physical mechanism as the redshift phenomenon observed in the cosmological model of the universe where celestial bodies move away from one another.

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: The radiation power of a commonly used helium-neon laser is 10 mW, with a beam divergence angle of \(\Delta \theta=2^{\prime}\), and a beam cross-section area \(\Delta S = 10 \ \mathrm{mm}^{2}\). Calculate the radiance \((B)\) of the helium-neon laser.
solution:
Given \(\Delta \theta=2^{\prime}=6 \times 10^{-4} \ \mathrm{rad}\), the solid angle of the beam can be approximated as \(\Delta \Omega \approx \pi(\Delta \theta)^{2}=10^{-6} \ \mathrm{sr}\). Within the beam, \(\cos \theta \approx 1\). Thus, the radiance of the beam is given by

\[
B = \frac{\Delta \Psi}{\Delta S \cdot \Delta \Omega \cdot \cos \theta} \approx 5 \times 10^{8} \ \mathrm{W/m}^{2} \cdot \mathrm{sr} 
\]

subject: Quantum Mechanics
problem: A cylindrical fluorescent tube with a diameter of $d=2.5 \, \text{cm}$ and a length of $l=40 \, \text{cm}$ causes an illuminance of $E = 21 \, \text{lx}$ at a distance of $r = 5 \, \text{m}$ in a direction perpendicular to the axis of the tube.
